facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1082 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1082 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1967 of the Delhi High Court in Company Appeal No. 3 of 1967. N. Khanna and Harbans Singh, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 7, 1967 of Delhi High Court in Company Appeal No. 3 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1967 of the Delhi High Court in Company Appeal No. 3 of 1967. N. Khanna and Harbans Singh, for the appellant. C. Khanna and Maharaj Krishan Chawla, for the respon- dent.

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company engaged in manufacture of electric conduit pipes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants private limited Company-is engaged in the manufacture of electric companyduit pipes. The respon- dent who is a director of the Company presented a petition in the High Court of Delhi under ss. 433 and 439 of the Companies Act, 1956,

facts.text: Respondent is a director of the company.

anchor.surface_text: The respon- dent who is a director of the Company presented a petition in the High Court of Delhi under ss. 433 and 439 of the Companies Act, 1956, for an order for companypulsory winding up of the Company.

facts.text: Respondent presented petition in Delhi High Court under ss. 433 and 439 of Companies Act 1956 for compulsory winding up.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is a director of the Company presented a petition in the High Court of Delhi under ss. 433 and 439 of the Companies Act, 1956, for an order for companypulsory winding up of the Company. The respondent claimed that it was just and equitable within the meaning of s. 443 f  of the Companies Act, 1956,

facts.text: Respondent claimed just and equitable to wind up under s.443(f) because one of three factories closed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed that it was just and equitable within the meaning of s. 443 f  of the Companies Act, 1956, to make an order for companypulsory winding up, because one of the three factories of the Company had been closed, that the accounts of the Company were number being shown to the respondent,

facts.text: Respondent claimed accounts of company not being shown to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: that numbermeeting of the Company had been held, numberbalance-sheet had been prepared and a letter of resignation purported to be signed 430 by the respondent had been forged. On July 18, 1966, Capoor, J., directed that numberice of the petition be issued to the appellant Company.

facts.text: Respondent claimed no balance-sheet prepared.

anchor.surface_text: numberbalance-sheet had been prepared and a letter of resignation purported to be signed 430 by the respondent had been forged. On July 18, 1966, Capoor, J., directed that numberice of the petition be issued to the appellant Company.

anchor.surface_text: and a letter of resignation purported to be signed 430 by the respondent had been forged. On July 18, 1966, Capoor, J., directed that numberice of the petition be issued to the appellant Company. The order has number been formally drawn up,

facts.text: On July 18, 1966, Capoor J directed notice of petition to appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1966, Capoor, J., directed that numberice of the petition be issued to the appellant Company. The order has number been formally drawn up, and it is number clear whether by that order it was intended to call upon the Company to show cause why the petition should number be admitted,

facts.text: Order of Capoor J not formally drawn up and unclear if for show cause or admission.

anchor.surface_text: The order has number been formally drawn up, and it is number clear whether by that order it was intended to call upon the Company to show cause why the petition should number be admitted, or that by the order the petition was admitted and numberice under r. 96 of the Companies  Court  Rules, 1959 was issued.

facts.text: Appellant company filed reply controverting allegations.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company filed its reply companytroverting the allegations made by the respondent. The Company also filed an application that the winding up petition filed by the respondent be taken off the file and be dismissed and that the petition in the meantime be number advertised.

facts.text: Company filed application to dismiss petition and not advertise.

anchor.surface_text: The Company also filed an application that the winding up petition filed by the respondent be taken off the file and be dismissed and that the petition in the meantime be number advertised.H. R. Khanna, J., held that the appropriate remedy of the respondent on the allegations of mismanagement of the affairs of the Company and oppression of the minority shareholders by the group of Anandi Lal was to file a petition under ss. 397 and 398 of the Companies Act.

facts.text: H.R. Khanna J held appropriate remedy under ss.397 and 398 for mismanagement and oppression.

anchor.surface_text: H. R. Khanna, J., held that the appropriate remedy of the respondent on the allegations of mismanagement of the affairs of the Company and oppression of the minority shareholders by the group of Anandi Lal was to file a petition under ss. 397 and 398 of the Companies Act. The learned Judge further held that the petition for winding up was instituted with a view to unfairly prejudice the interests of the shareholders of the Company,

facts.text: H.R. Khanna J held petition instituted to unfairly prejudice shareholders, respondent set up rival factory.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge further held that the petition for winding up was instituted with a view to unfairly prejudice the interests of the shareholders of the Company, respondent having set up a rival factory in the name of his son for manufacturing electric companyduit pipes. The learned Judge directed that the petition be number advertised and be. dismissed.

facts.text: H.R. Khanna J directed petition not be advertised and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: respondent having set up a rival factory in the name of his son for manufacturing electric companyduit pipes. The learned Judge directed that the petition be number advertised and be. dismissed. In appeal against the order passed by H. R. Khanna, J., the High Court of Delhi held that under the Companies  Court  Rules, 1959,

facts.text: Delhi High Court held once petition admitted, must advertise forthwith under rules.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against the order passed by H. R. Khanna, J., the High Court of Delhi held that under the Companies  Court  Rules, 1959, once a petition is admitted to the file, the Court is bound forthwith to advertise the petition. The companypany challenges that order in this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and remanded the case to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed. The High Court has disposed of the appeal on a ground of procedure and has number companysidered whether the view of H. R. Khanna, J., that in the exercise of the inherent power for the ends of justice and for prevention of the abuse of the process of Court, the petition should number be advertised, is companyrect. The case is therefore remanded with the direction that the High Court do deal with and dispose of the appeal according to law. There will be numberorder as to its companyts in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court erred in holding petition must be advertised even before application to stay.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court directed that the petition for winding up be advertised,the High Court was bound to companysider whether the view expressed by H. R. Khanna,, J., was right. For reasons already set out, in our judgment, the High Court erred in holding that a petition for winding up must be advertised even before the application filed by the Company for staying the proceeding for the ends of justice, or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court.

arguments.claim: View that court must advertise as soon as admitted is contrary to r.96 and would enable harassment and blackmail as advertisement injures company business.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court that the Court must, as soon as the petition is admitted, advertise the petition is companytrary to the plain terms of r. 96. Such a view, if accepted, would make the Court an instrument, in possible cases, of harassment and even of blackmail,

holdings.text: A petition for winding up cannot be placed for hearing before the Court unless the petition is advertised, but that does not mean it must be advertised as soon as admitted.

anchor.surface_text: A petition for winding up cannot be placed for hearing before the Court, unless the petition is advertised that is clear from the terms of r. 24 2 . But that is number to say that as soon as the petition is admitted, it must be advertised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of r.24 requiring ad before hearing but not mandating immediate ad upon admission; distinguishes hearing requirement from admission.

holdings.text: The High Court has three procedural options under r.96: (i) notice to show cause against admission; (ii) admit, fix hearing, notice before ad directions; (iii) admit, fix hearing, order ad.

holdings.text: The power to entertain applications to restrain advertisement for ends of justice or abuse prevention is inherent in the Court and not limited by the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court that the Court must, as soon as the petition is admitted, advertise the petition is companytrary to the plain terms of r. 96. holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual contradiction with r.96 plus policy against harm from premature advertisement.

anchor.surface_text: A petition for winding up cannot be placed for hearing before the Court, unless the petition is advertised that is clear from the terms of r. 24 2 . But that is number to say that as soon as the petition is admitted, it must be advertised.

The appeal is allowed. The High Court has disposed of the appeal on a ground of procedure and has number companysidered whether the view of H. R. Khanna, J., that in the exercise of the inherent power for the ends of justice and for prevention of the abuse of the process of Court, the petition should number be advertised, is companyrect. The case is therefore remanded with the direction that the High Court do deal with and dispose of the appeal according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court that the Court must, as soon as the petition is admitted, advertise the petition is companytrary to the plain terms of r. 96.
